page.title: 9.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn that completing the square can be used to solve any quadratic equation, including equations that involve rational numbers that are not integers.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Solve by completing the square when given a quadratic equation in which the coefficient of the squared term is 1.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.3.1: Solving Equations with Fractions
  • 9.3.2: Using Completing the Square to Solve Equations
    • 9.3.2: Self Check
    • 9.3.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.3.3: Solve by Completing the Square
    • 9.3.3: Self Check
    • 9.3.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.3.4: Completing the Square with Fractions

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.3.5: Practice
  • 9.3.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.3.1: Solving Equations with Fractions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Solve each equation mentally.

  1. \(x+x=\frac14\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=\frac18\)


  1. \((\frac{3}{2})^2=x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=\frac94\)


  1. \(\frac{3}{5}+x=\frac95\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=\frac65\)


  1. \(\frac{1}{12}+x=\frac14\)

Write down your answer in simplest form, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=\frac16\)

page.title: 9.3.2: Using Completing the Square to Solve Equations
page.contents:
Activity

Completing the square can be used to solve quadratic equations.

Example: Solve \(x^2+8x-2=0\).

To complete the square to solve an equation, follow these steps:

Step 1
Write the equation in the form \(ax^2+bx=c\).
\(x^2+8x=-2\)

Step 2
Complete the square by finding \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
\((\frac{b}{2})^2=(\frac{8}{2})^2=16\)

Step 3
Add the value to both sides of the equation.
\(x^2+8x+16=-2+16\)

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial and simplify the constants.
\((x+4)^2=14\)

Step 5
Take the square root of each side (remember the plus-minus sign with the constant).
\(\sqrt{(x+4)^2}=\sqrt{14}\)
\(x+4= \pm \sqrt{14}\)

Step 6
Write two separate equations and solve each.
\(x + 4 = \sqrt{14}\)  or  \(x + 4 =\; - \;\sqrt{14}\)
\(x = -4 + \sqrt{14}\)  or  \(x =\; -\;4\; –\; \sqrt{14}\)

Solve each equation by completing the square. In part a, select the value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square. In part b, choose the two roots.

  1. \((x−3)(x+1)=5\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Enter the value:

Correct! \((\frac{b}{2})^2 = 1\)

The correct answer is \((\frac{b}{2})^2 = 1\).

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.

Correct! \(x = -2\), \(x = 4\)

The correct answers are: \(x = -2\), \(x = 4\).

  1. \(x^2+\frac{1}{2}x=\frac{3}{16}\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Enter the value:

Compare your answer:

\((\frac{b}{2})^2= \frac{1}{16}\)


  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.

Correct! \(x=\frac14\), \(x=-\frac34\)

The correct answers are: \(x=\frac14\), \(x=-\frac34\).

  1. \(x^2+3x+\frac{8}{4}=0\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Enter the value:

Compare your answer:

\((\frac{b}{2})^2= \frac94\)


  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.

Correct! \(x = -2\), \(x = -1\)

The correct answers are: \(x = -2\), \(x = -1\).

  1. \((7−x)(3−x)+3=0\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((\frac{b}{2})^2= 25\)

The correct answer is \((\frac{b}{2})^2= 25\).

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.

Correct! \(x = 6\), \(x = 4\)

The correct answers are: \(x = 6\), \(x = 4\).

  1. \(x^2+1.6x+0.63=0\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((\frac{b}{2})^2=0.64\)

The correct answer is \((\frac{b}{2})^2=0.64\).

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.

Correct! \(x = -0.7\), \(x = -0.9\)

The correct answers are: \(x = -0.7\), \(x = -0.9\).



Video: Solve by Completing the Square

Watch the following video to learn more about solving to complete the square.

page.title: 9.3.2: Self Check
page.contents: After solving using completing the square, what are the zeros of the quadratic equation \(x^2+5x+\frac{9}{4}=0\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: After adding the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\), make sure to take the square root of both sides. The answer is \(x=\frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\), not a zero. The answer is \(x=\frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\).

That's correct! Check yourself: Move the \(\frac94\) to the other side of the equation then complete the square and add \(\frac{25}{4}\) to each side. Take the square root of each side then factor. The equation becomes \(x+ \frac{5}{2}= \pm \;2\). Solve for \(x\) and these are the zeros.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The perfect square binomial created is \((x+\frac{5}{2})^2\) but this does not give the zero. The answer is \(x=\frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\).

page.title: 9.3.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Completing the Square with Fractions

Completing the square can be a useful method for solving quadratic equations in cases in which it is not easy to rewrite an expression in factored form. For example, let's solve this equation:

\(x^2 + 5x - \frac{75}{4}=0\)

First, we'll add \(\frac{75}{4}\) to each side to make things easier on ourselves.

\(x^2+5x-\frac{75}{4}+\frac{75}{4}=0+\frac{75}{4}\)

\(x^2+5x=\frac{75}{4}\)

To complete the square, take \(\frac12\) of the coefficient of the linear term 5, which is \(\frac52\), and square it, which is \(\frac{25}{5}\). Add this to each side:

\(x^2 +5x +\frac{25}{4}=\frac{75}{4}+\frac{25}{4}\)

 \(x^2+5x +\frac{25}{4}=\frac{100}{4}\)

Notice that \(\frac{100}{4}\) is equal to 25 and rewrite it:

\(x^2+5x+\frac{25}{4}=25\)

Since the left side is now a perfect square, let's rewrite it:

\((x+\frac{5}{2})^2=25\)

For this equation to be true, one of these equations must be true:

\(x+\frac{5}{2}=5\) or \(x+\frac{5}{2}=-5\)

To finish up, we can subtract \(\frac52\) from each side of the equal sign in each equation.

\(x=5-\frac52\) or \(x=-5-\frac52\)

\(x=\frac52\) or \(x=-\frac{15}{2}\)

\(x=2\frac12\) or \(x=-7\frac12\)

It takes some practice to become proficient at completing the square, but it makes it possible to solve many more equations than you could by methods you learned previously.

Try It: Completing the Square with Fractions

Solve \(x^2+3x-4=0\) using completing the square, then find the zeros of the quadratic equation.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the zeros after using completing the square:

Step 1
Add the constant to the other side of the equation.
\(x^2+3x=4\)

Step 2
Complete the square.
\((\frac{3}{2})^2=\frac94\)

Step 3
Add the constant to each side.
\(x^2+3x+\frac{9}{4}=\frac{16}{4}+\frac94\)

Step 4
Simplify and factor the perfect square trinomial.
\((x+\frac{3}{2})^2=\frac{25}{4}\)

Step 5
Take the square root of both sides of the equation.
\(x+\frac{3}{2}= \pm \frac{5}{2}\)

Step 6
Write the two equations and solve. 
\(x+\frac{3}{2}=\frac{5}{2}\) and \(x+\frac{3}{2}=-\frac{5}{2}\)
\(x=1\)                             \(x=-4\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.3.3: Solve by Completing the Square
page.contents:
Activity

Here are four equations followed by worked solutions of the equations. Each solution has at least one error.

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2+14x=-24\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr} x^{2}+14 x & =-24 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}+14 x+28 & =4 & \text { Step 2 } \\ (x+7)^{2} & =4 & \text { Step 3 } \\ x+7 & =2 & \text { Step 4 } \\ x+7 & =-2 & \text { Step 5 } \\ x & =-5 \text { and } x=9 & \text { Step 6 } \\ \end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=-2\) and \(x=-12\)

Error: In Step 2, the number being added, 28, is not a perfect square. It should be 49.


  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−10x+16=0\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr} x^{2}-10 x+16 & =0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 & =9 & \text { Step 2 } \\ (x-5)^{2} & =9 & \text { Step 3 } \\ x-5 & =9 & \text { Step 4 } \\ x-5 & =-9 & \text { Step 5 } \\ x=14 & \text { and } x=-4 & \text { Step 6 } \end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=8\) and \(x=2\)

Errors: Step 4 should have 3 on the right side, not 9. Step 5 should have -3 on the right side, not -9.


  1. Solve the equation \(x^2+2.4x=-0.8\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr}x^2+2.4x=-0.8\;\;\text{ Step 1}& \\ x^2+2.4x+1.44=0.64\quad\text{Step 2}& \\ (x+1.2)^2=0.64\quad\text{Step 3}& \\ x+1.2=0.8\quad\text{Step 4}& \\ x=-0.4\quad\text{Step 5}&\end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=-0.4\) and \(x=-2\) 

Error: In Step 4, only the positive square root is written and the negative square root is neglected.


  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−\frac{6}{5}x+\frac{1}{5}=0\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rrr} x^{2}-\frac{6}{5} x+\frac{1}{5} & =0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}-\frac{6}{5} x+\frac{9}{25} & =\frac{9}{25} & \text { Step 2 } \\ \left(x-\frac{3}{5}\right)^{2} & =\frac{9}{25} & \text { Step 3 } \\ x-\frac{3}{5} & =\frac{3}{5} & \text { Step 4 } \\ x-\frac{3}{5} & =-\frac{3}{5} & \text { Step 5 } \\ x=\frac{6}{5} & \text { and } x=0 & \text { Step 6 } \end{array}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x=1\) and \(x=\frac{1}{5}\)

Errors: For example:
In Step 2, different amounts are added to each side. On the left, \(\frac{4}{25}\) is added. On the right, \(\frac{9}{25}\) is added. Or: While \(\frac{9}{25}\) is added on the right side, \(\frac{1}{5}\) was only subtracted from the left side. Other explanations may also be accurate.

page.title: 9.3.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Examine the work shown. Which of the following is the error that took place when the equation was solved by completing the square?

\(x^2-6x-7=0\)

\(x^2-6x=7\)

\(x^2-6x+9=16\)

\((x-3)^2=16\)

\(x-3=4\)

\(x=7\)

answer.answer_text: The 7 should have been subtracted from each side.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The inverse operation was correctly used and 7 was added to both sides. The correct answer is: When taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

answer.answer_text: When taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.
answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: When taking \(\sqrt{(x-3)^2}=\sqrt{16}\) the positive and negative 4s must be considered so that \(x-3= \pm \; 4\).

answer.answer_text: When completing the square, the wrong number was found for \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: \((\frac{6}{2})^2=9\) so the square was completed correctly. The correct answer is when taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

answer.answer_text: This equation cannot be solved by completing the square.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This problem can be solved by completing the square since it is a quadratic equation with a real coefficient of \(x\). The correct answer is: When taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

page.title: 9.3.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Spotting the Error When Solving Quadratics

To find the error when solving quadratics, it is helpful to first solve the problem on your own.

Solve the quadratic equation by completing the square and finding its zeros. Identify the error in the worked solution below.

\(\begin{array}{ll} x^{2}+10 x-34=0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}+10 x=34 & \text { Step 2 } \\ x^{2}+10 x+25=34-25 & \text { Step 3 } \\ (x+5)^{2}=9 & \text { Step 4 } \\ x+5=\pm \; 3 & \text { Step 5 } \\ x=-8, x=-2 & \text { Step 6 } \end{array} \)

Now, find the error by working through the problem and comparing steps:

\(\begin{array}{ll} x^{2}+10 x-34=0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}+10 x=34 & \text { Step 2 } \\ x^{2}+10 x+25=34+25 & \text { Step 3 } \end{array} \)

In Step 3, 25 was added to the left side of the equation, but 25 was SUBTRACTED from the right side of the equation. Equations must remain balanced, and 25 should be added to each side of the equation.

Try It: Spotting the Error When Solving Quadratics

Examine the steps below and identify the error in solving the quadratic equation by completing the square:

\(\begin{array}{lcc}x^2+8x+7=0&\text{ Step 1 }& \\ x^2+8x=-7&\text{ Step 2 }& \\ x^2+8x+16=-7+16&\text{ Step 3 }& \\ (x+4)^2=9&\text{ Step 4 }& \\ x+4=3&\text{ Step 5 }& \\ x=-1&\text{ Step 6 }&\end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the error when completing the square:

Work through the steps on your own and compare:

\(\begin{array}{lc}x^2+8x+7=0&\text{ Step 1 } \\ x^2+8x=-7&\text{ Step 2 } \\ x^2+8x+16=-7+16&\text{ Step 3 } \\ (x+4)^2=9&\text{ Step 4 } \\ x+4=\pm3&\text{ Step 5 } \\ x=-1,x=-7&\text{ Step 6 }\end{array}\)

The error occurred in Step 5 when the plus-minus sign was not included after taking the square root of each side. This led to the second possible equation not being written.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.3.4: Completing the Square with Fractions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The solutions to this equation are \(x = \frac{3}{4}\) and \(x=\frac{1}{4}\). Show how to find those solutions by completing the square. \(x^2−x+\frac{3}{16}=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}x^2-x+\frac3{16}&=&0\\x^2-x+\frac14&=&-\frac3{16}+\frac14=-\frac3{16}+\frac4{16}=\frac1{16}\\x^2-x+\frac14&=&\frac1{16}\\\sqrt{\left(x-\frac12\right)^2}&=&\sqrt{\frac1{16}}\\x-\frac12&=&\pm\frac14\\x-\frac12&=&\frac14\\x-\frac12&=&-\frac14\end{array}\)
\( \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=\frac{1}{4} \text { and } x=\frac{3}{4}\)

page.title: 9.3.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For the expressions in questions 1–4, choose which number would make the expression a perfect square. Then, choose an equivalent expression in factored form.

  1. \(x^2+3x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2+3x\) a perfect square?

Correct! \(\frac94\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac94\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2+3x\)?

Correct! \(x(x + 3)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(x(x + 3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+0.6x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2+0.6x\) a perfect square?

Correct! 0.09

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: 0.09. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2+0.6x\)?

Correct! \(x(x+0.06)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(x(x+0.06)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2-11x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2-11x\) a perfect square?

Correct! \(\frac{121}{4}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac{121}{4}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2-11x\)?

Correct! \(x(x-11)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(x(x-11)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2-\frac{5}{2}x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2-\frac{5}{2}x\) a perfect square?

Correct! \(\frac{25}{16}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2 and 9.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac{25}{16}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2-\frac{5}{2}x\)?

Correct! \(x(x-\frac52)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.2.2 and 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(x(x-\frac52)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2+x\) a perfect square?

Correct! \(\frac14\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.2.2 and 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac14\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2-\frac{3}{2}x\) a perfect square?  

Correct! \(\frac{9}{16}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.2.2 and 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(\frac{9}{16}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Noah is solving the equation \(x^2+8x+15=3\). He begins by rewriting the expression on the left in factored form and writes \((x+3)(x+5)=3\). He does not know what to do next. 
  1. Do you think using the factored form is the best way for Noah to solve this equation?

Correct! No. Noah should use completing the square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.3.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is No. Noah should use completing the square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve the original equation, then choose the two roots.

Correct! \(x=-2\) and \(x=-6\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.2.2 and 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-2\) and \(x=-6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. An equation and its solutions are given. Solve the equation by completing the square, then choose whether you agree or disagree with the given solutions.
  1. \(x^2+20x+50=14\). The solutions are \(x=-18\) and \(x=2\).

Correct! Disagree. The correct solutions are \(x=-18\) and \(x=-2\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.3 and 9.3.4. Are you using it the right way

The correct answer is Disagree. The correct solutions are \(x=-18\) and \(x=-2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+1.6x=0.36\). The solutions are \(x=-1.8\) and \(x=0.2\).

Correct! Agree. \(x=-1.8\) and \(x=0.2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.3 and 9.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Agree. \(x=-1.8\) and \(x=0.2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2-5x=\frac{11}{4}\). The solutions are \(x=\frac{11}{4}\) and \(x=-12\).

Correct! Disagree. The correct solutions are \(x=\frac{11}{2}\) and \(x=-\frac12\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.3 and 9.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Disagree. The correct solutions are \(x=\frac{11}{2}\) and \(x=-\frac12\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve each equation, then choose the two roots.
  1. \(x^2-0.5x=0.5\)

Correct! \(x=-0.5\) and \(x=1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2–9.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-0.5\) and \(x=1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+0.8x=0.09\)

Correct! \(x=-0.9\) and \(x=0.1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2–9.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-0.9\) and \(x=0.1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+\frac{13}{3}x=\frac{56}{36}\)

Correct! \(x=-\frac{14}{3}\) and \(x = \frac{1}{3}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.3.2–9.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-\frac{14}{3}\) and \(x = \frac{1}{3}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.3.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Solve by completing the square when given a quadratic equation in which the coefficient of the squared term is 1.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.3.1: Solving Equations with Fractions
    • In this activity, you mentally solved equations with fractions and exponents.
  • 9.3.2: Using Completing the Square to Solve Equations
    • In this activity, you solved quadratic equations involving rational numbers including decimals and fractions.
    • 9.3.2: Self Check
    • 9.3.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.3.3: Solve by Completing the Square
    • In this activity, you examined the steps to solving quadratic equations by completing the square and identified the step where an error occurred.
    • 9.3.3: Self Check
    • 9.3.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.3.4: Completing the Square with Fractions
    • In this activity, you showed how to get the given zeros of the quadratic by completing the square.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.3.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
